body: Thanks for @ivankelly  and @merlimat 's review, 1103 merged

@merlimat 
> One thing that might also help is to include the producer/consumer exception message in the 500 error. That might help to quickly find out what the issue is (on the websocket proxy side) without having to search the proxy logs.

Fixed ConsumerHandler and ReaderHandler.
ProducerHandler has already included the exception message in the error response.
In addition, I have added some tests.

We consider the following situation:
* Default: limit the number of max clients (e.g. 100)
* For namespaces where topics are 'huge': relax the number of max clients (e.g. 1000) by administrater (not tenant)

Shouldn't we do so?
@sijie Thanks, have changed it. receiverQueueSize was added to test some functionality. added it back here.

> Am I right to choose Pulsar as the right option to realize the application? 

That is exactly the same scenario as Sherpa use case, so I would definitely say that it is a good match. We literally designed for that use case :)

> would you give me some advice? thanks a lot!

Sure, shoot up any question/doubts either here, in the mailing lists or in the Slack channel.
would like to close this one and open a new PR.

Sure, let's merge and then link it on the homepage after the cleanup.

Hi, Merlimat:

When in the sync SQL database scenario, what do you think about CockroachDB(a mimic of google spanner) or TiDB(from China). 
The above 2 databases are 3rd generation DB: NewSQL DB.
The fantastic feature of CockroachDB is ditrubuted databases, which support muti-datacenters synchronization.
Before I found "Pulsar project",  I was considering using CockroachDB or TiDB  in the database sychronization of different datacenters through “Internet” (Not dedicated network). 
1.Do you think CockrouchDB is suitable for my application?
2.What's the best practice of such scenario?
@merlimat Thanks for your advice!

I know about Spanner, though I have no insight about the replication implementation in CockroardDB or TiDB. 

In Pulsar, the replication is one of the key feature of the system and it has been battle tested in several year of production usage, replicating millions of topics across 8+ datacenters in full mesh. 

We have had a number of network outages especially on the Pacific ocean links that lasted for several days of seriously degraded bandwidth issues and we were able to "make it through".

Cockroachdb uses Raft, and the replication is strongly consistent.

Doing strict consensus across the WAN will have a penalty, does not matter
what the protocol is.  Latencies will be higher.

The change looks good. 👍 

Let me confirm the nomenclature:
I think the term "topic" or "topic name" indicates the fully qualified path like
```
persistent://prop/cluster/ns/t1
```
Are there any term to indicate only the last part (i.e., t1)?
LGTM 👍

>  I think the term "topic" or "topic name" indicates the fully qualified path like 
> `persistent://prop/cluster/ns/t1`
> Are there any term to indicate only the last part (i.e., t1)?

Good point. We don't have a very consistent name for that. In some places in the code we refer to `t1` as "topic", in others we use "localName". 

This is another area where we should improve the terminology, though this is outside the scope of this PR. For now, I have converted usages of "destination" to "topic" regardless on whether they referred to the local name or the qualified one.

We just need to mention, in our bare metal documentation, that auto-recovery can be either run as a separate component, or by enabling a flag to run the replication worker along with the bookies.

@maskit I think the test is wrong. 

It is testing with some garbage input and trying to skip some fields. But this line: 

```java
        assertTrue(inputStream.skipField(WireFormat.WIRETYPE_START_GROUP));
```

Would assume that we had some previous "fieldId" already, which since we are reading garbage, we didn't have. 

That is as expected, it all depends on the generated code to not trying to read `WIRETYPE_START_GROUP` without reading the field id before.

> How is it different for HTTP connections?

TLS connections, in general, can be made without client certificates and authentication. It's nothing to do with HTTP - this is for the binary protocol (pulsar+ssl://...)

> We should have some tests to validate what happens with the 3 possible options in the broker side.

ClientAuth.OPTIONAL and ClientAuth.NONE is same for us 
Hence added one more negative test case to test ClientAuth.REQUIRE

> What kind of changes are there for the client? Is the exception going to be different?

The client doesn't need to make any changes except that this setting mandates clients sending TLS certificates when connecting to TLS port. Details are in  https://netty.io/4.0/api/io/netty/handler/ssl/ClientAuth.html which I have added in the comments.

This is pretty standard settings and makes sense when you setup entities with public IP like our Pulsar Proxy. This allows netty to reject requests *without* TLS certs on connect and not wait for authentication to take place in handleConnect.

> TLS connections, in general, can be made without client certificates and authentication. It's nothing to do with HTTP - this is for the binary protocol (pulsar+ssl://...)

Sure but one can always do lookup on `https://broker/` and then use TLS on wire protocol, my question how the HTTPS server is affected from that flag, since we should provide the same behavior across the two of them.

> javax.net.ssl.SSLException: SSLEngine closed already 

Exactly, my point is that we should treat the exception accordingly and give error to application (eg: authentication failed.. .) without trying to reconnect again.
retest this please

@zhaijack please check my earlier comment, I think it got hidden  after the last changes you pushed, about using the `Timer` from the `ClientImpl` instance. That will ensure to not having a thread per topic, or to have a task blocked when the listener executor is blocked by the application.
retest this please // seem to be flakes
Thanks for the instructions @merlimat , updated it.

IIRC, I set clientAuth "OPTIONAL" intentionally. If TLS Auth plugin is used, the plugin ensure that a valid client cert is provided. TLS connection may be already established (without checking client certs), but the client shouldn't be able to anything on the connection since authentication is not completed.
retest this please // flake
ping @merlimat , please review this new commit at your convenience.

@jai1 What is the intention of this change? Is it to add an earlier level of protection so that you can configure Netty to directly reject connections if the client doesn't have a valid (trusted) certificate? 

I'm ok with this kind of change, though I would suggest to: 
 * Ensure client library treats it in the same way as an auth failure, like today
 * The configuration flag can be simplified into `requireTrustedClientCertificate`
 * The same behavior should be applied also for HTTPS calls, if we require valid certificate, we should not pass not accept the HTTP connection, irrespective of the configured authentication plugin.

@maskit @merlimat 
- Once the client is connected the authentication happens on handleConnect, if I am a mischief maker (not using client library) I can directly call other commands and skip handleConnect - eg. call handleGetTopicsOfNamespace, closeProducer etc. Not all commands authenticate or authorize. 

- My main aim is to not allow ppl to connect if their cert is not a part of our trust store.

- Yes, client library handles this failure as any other failure to connect like if serviceUrl is not correctly configured. The error I sent `routines:OPENSSL_internal:PEER_DID_NOT_RETURN_A_CERTIFICATE` was server side error. Client side error is 
`3775 [pulsar-client-io-60-1] WARN org.apache.pulsar.client.impl.ConnectionPool - [[id: 0xced4a39e, L:/127.0.0.1:57458 ! R:localhost/127.0.0.1:15082]] Connection handshake failed: org.apache.pulsar.client.api.PulsarClientException: Connection already closed`

- requireTrustedClientCertificate is a bit different since even now we reject the certificates which are not trusted but that is done during handleConnect. ClientAuth is a more colloquial term which Java SSL handlers use. 

> The same behavior should be applied also for HTTPS calls, if we require a valid certificate, we should not pass not accept the HTTP connection, irrespective of the configured authentication plugin.
- I have not tested HTTPS flow because as of now my main aim is to make proxy more secure since it is on a public IP. (Proxy understands only binary protocol). HTTPS also has an option to do the same we are playing with it for the Kay Value DB that we have in Yahoo. I will open a ticket for the HTTPS part and resolve it next week since I am working on something else this sprint.
retest this please

> Once the client is connected the authentication happens on handleConnect, if I am a mischief maker (not using client library) I can directly call other commands and skip handleConnect - eg. call handleGetTopicsOfNamespace, closeProducer etc. Not all commands authenticate or authorize.

Though all commands are verifying the state of `ServerCnx` is `Connected`. But yes, there might be bugs.

> My main aim is to not allow ppl to connect if their cert is not a part of our trust store.

Correct and I agree on the value of the goal

> requireTrustedClientCertificate is a bit different since even now we reject the certificates which are not trusted but that is done during handleConnect. ClientAuth is a more colloquial term which Java SSL handlers use.

You are mixing 2 factors: 
 1. TLS encryption
 2. TLS client authentication

For the first, you don't need authentication, or you may be using a different auth provider (think Kerberos over TLS), but still might require (or not) the client certificate to be valid.

For the second we want to identify who a client is, and that inevitably imply having a trusted client certificate. 

The flag `requireTrustedClientCertificate` applies for both cases, although for (2) it's just a pre-check and the certificate is validated anyway in the Connect/Connected handler.

> I have not tested HTTPS flow because as of now my main aim is to make proxy more secure since it is on a public IP. (Proxy understands only binary protocol). HTTPS also has an option to do the same we are playing with it for the Kay Value DB that we have in Yahoo. I will open a ticket for the HTTPS part and resolve it next week since I am working on something else this sprint.

I'd rather have the same behavior, because this is not applying just to proxy. If we want to require a valid client certificate we should do that in both protocol.

@merlimat added log4j2 file, remove log4j1

@mgodave , the `AuthMethod` enum was used in Pulsar before we realized that it was a problem to plug in an arbitrary authentication plugin. For that we switched to "string" based identifier well before open-sourcing Pulsar. 

The issue was, and I suspect that still is, that there are applications running older Pulsar client  version. The test was to ensure that this client can still connect to new brokers. In fact, there's a specific check for that enum in `ServerCnx` in order to maintain compatibility.

ok, I could not see any place it was being used other than an old test.
Feel free to close.

Yes, for sure, the `@Deprecated` was just a lazy shortcut for that.

I added it then reverted it. I *think* we only need it on the server. We
can tag messages as they come in and before we persist them to the topic,
right? Even if that's the case it *might* be useful to return the version
to the client.

> We can tag messages as they come in and before we persist them to the topic, right?  

That would mean that we need to re-serialize the protobuf each time. If the producer sets it, we just take whatever buffer we have and store that in bk.

I'm updating the code. In the ServerCnx we store a list of the Producers
for a Topic. Each producer has a publishing schema associated with it and
will tag the messages as they are produced, this way the client is
completely uninvolved. Does this sound reasonable? I'm in deep and it's
uncharted territory for me on this codebase.

NOTE:

Ideally I would like to contribute this module as part of log4j2 - https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2 . However we would like to use this module for pulsar-functions in #1314 , so make the initial contribution here. At the same time, I would send a PR to log4j2 as well.

retest this please
sounds like a good approach to take. +1

The problem with that is that it would make standalone to not work outside localhost (with default config.

I think a better option would be to do what I was describing in https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/issues/1152#issuecomment-363842493

Force the "proxy" flag in standalone, so that the advertised address is not a concern anymore.

I completely agree with the goal of simplification, but I think the problem is that each property is not of the same type: some are simple long/string scalars, while others are complex objects.

The validations performed also are kind of different for each property.

Finally, while the refactoring looks good for REST, I would still prefer to have individual operations on the Java/CLI since it makes the user life easier, by discovering all the possible methods/commands.
